description.narrative: PIMS 5437: Conservation and sustainable use of Pamir Alay and Tien Shan ecosystems for snow leopard protection and sustainable community livelihoods

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative: 1.1. During the reporting period, the project prepared the necessary regulatory documents to include Sangvor Zakaznik in the Tajik National Park. The package of documents on upgrading the status of Sangvor Zakaznik was submitted to the Committee for Environmental Protection (CoEP) for review and approval. Along with that, during the reporting period, the State Institution for SPNA was returned under the jurisdiction of the CoEP from the Forestry Agency. The area of protected areas falling under IUCN Category I and Category II is 2777018 ha, and will increase up to 2,837,018 ha once Sangvor Zakaznik is included into the Sangvor Section of the Tajik National Park. 1.2. According to the State Institution for SPNA, the total annual budget allocation for all categories of protected areas (I-IV) in 2020 made 3,420,000 TJS or 330,761 USD (note: the exchange rate is 10.3398 as of 30.10.2020). 1.3. Midterm METT scores make 66 scores for Sangvor section of TNP (including Sangvor Zakaznik), and 58 scores for Lyakhsh section of TNP. 1.4. As of 2020, the total number of active rangers make 32, including 16 in Sangvor branch of TNP and 16 in Lyakhsh branch of TNP. 1.5. 40% of Lyakhsh and 50% of Sangvor TNP sections are under safe and effective monitoring and enforcement regime. 1.6. More than 500 people (80 of them women), including 18 rangers and 2 community liaison experts financially benefit from participation in PA protection and patrolling, as well as enjoy favorable terms for collection of forest resources, firewood, medicinal herbs, beekeeping and use of pastures in Lyakhsh and Sangvor sections of TNP. 2.1. In the reporting period, due to favorable climatic conditions (intensive snow and rainfall in the mountains) and late transfer of cattle to high-altitude pastures, the days of grazing reduced by 20-30 days in winter pastures and by 30-40 days in summer pastures. 2.2. According to expert field assessments and reconnaissance research, the productivity of high mountain pastures in the project areas of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz ranges from 4.4 to 5.8 tons per hectare. 2.3. According to project experts, 40-60% of the total grass cover on the high mountain pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz make the species edible for wild animals and livestock. The percentage of eatable and edible species was identified using the moving method in selected plots. 2.4. To date, four (4) Pasture User Unions have approved pasture management plans and are implementing them in high-altitude pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz areas. The project partner, the Pasture Ameliorative Trust has developed a methodological guide for rehabilitation of degraded pastures; and based on this 3 workshops on methods of pasture rotation, rehabilitation and management were offered for representatives of pasture user unions (attended by 90 members of pasture user unions, of which 10 were women). 2.5. During the reporting period, the project small grants program supported three (3) community projects in Ayni and Shamsiddin-Shokhin districts aimed at restoring pastures and introducing alternative energy technologies: (a) sustainable pasture management: - 13 households in Dashtijum village of Shamsiddin-Shokhin district benefit from a grant project on building corrals for 600 small cattle (10 direct beneficiaries, including 5 women, and 30 indirect beneficiaries, including 12 women). - 40 households in the Dashtijum Jamoat of the Shamsiddin Shokhin district benefit from grant project on restoration of 4 hectares of degraded forest ecosystems and 6 hectares of pastures located in snow leopard habitats (25 direct beneficiaries and 220 indirect beneficiaries, including 75 women). (b) Fuel and energy technologies: 508 people directly and 24,894 indirectly (including 12,355 women) benefit from a grant project on creation of a demonstration site for energy-efficiency technologies at the boarding school in Mehron village, Gorno-Machinsky district, where solar batteries and water heaters were installed. 60 people, including 14 women from pasture user unions, local communities and dekhkan farms in Rasht, Khujand and Kulob districts, were trained in the requirements and rules of preparing small grant project proposals and participating in small grant projects during three training workshops offered by the project. 2.6. During 2019-2020, 150 hectares of high-altitude pastures and 42 hectares of high-altitude forests were restored by pasture user unions and forest departments in 10 project areas. During the reporting period, 2,000 ha of high-altitude pastures in Shahristan, Ayni, Rasht, Tojikobod, Lakhsh, Sangvor, Muminobod, Khovaling and Shamsiddin Shokhin districts have been restored and are under sustainable management. The cumulative progress for highland forests under restoration/rehabilitation regime in the Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaz project areas is 4,000 hectares (2,500 hectares were turned into restoration /rehabilitation regime during the reporting period). These achievements were supported by the project activities in providing 4 tons of fruit crop seeds and 6,000 seedlings for pasture user unions and forestry departments in project areas. At the same time, 18 units of machinery and equipment (mini-tractors, shovels, pumps, pipes and networks) were handed over to pasture user unions and forestry departments in Shahristan, Ayni, Rasht, Lakhsh, Sangvor, Shamsiddin-Shokhin, Muminabad and Khovaling project areas to support rehabilitation and restoration of high mountain pastures and forests. 2.7. During the reporting period, representatives of PFM committees took an active part in implementing project activities. More than 20 people, including 5 women, took part in 3 workshops in Shakhristan, Baljuvan and Sangvor districts devoted to improvement of forest management, use of biotechnical methods for restoration of degraded forests, and law enforcement. 2.8. During the reporting period, 5 workshops on monitoring of biodiversity and wildlife law enforcement were held, attended by 75 people (including 10 women) from the Committee for Environmental Protection, the Forestry Agency, local administration, communities and farmers, etc. Project partners organized 10 workshops and training sessions on public monitoring, data transmission and law enforcement in the transborder landscapes of Rasht and Lakhsh districts, attended by representatives of customs services, border guards and environmental authorities (totally 200 participants, including 20 women). 3.1. Currently the project prepares the terms of reference for the development and implementation of Snow Leopard Information Management System (SLIMS). This system will aim monitoring of snow leopards and prey not only within protected areas, but also throughout the country and beyond. For this purpose, the project cooperates with GSLEP on signing a transboundary memorandum with Central Asian countries. 3.2. On March 7, 2020, a meeting of the National Snow Leopard Committee was held. The following issues were considered: -Cooperation with international consultants; -SMART patrolling and the use of mobile technologies; -SLIM monitoring; -Regional cooperation; -Testing innovative regional GSLEP programs and participating in snow leopard events; -Action plan and development of mechanisms for its implementation; -Monitoring the Small Grants Program and assessing their socio-economic efficiency; -Information programs and events to be held in the regions of the country and nationwide; -Support of international initiatives of the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan and preparation of side events in relevant format; -Publications and PR materials 3.3. The National Action Plan on conservation of snow leopard ecosystems (NAP) was updated to enable synergies with the global strategy on snow leopard conservation. The document was complemented by activities involving the aspects of transboundary cooperation and adaptation to climate change for conservation of snow leopard ecosystems. The document was agreed at the level of the Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan, that was a first step in testing its feasibility with regard to the above-mentioned developments, and given this process is controlled though the Snow Leopard Conservation Committee meetings. The second step will be the finalization of the NAP in cooperation with the Committee for Environmental Protection for the following approval. A number of NAP activities aimed at monitoring and assessment of high-altitude ecosystems, training on patrolling and data collection were outlined for implementation in 2019 during the two meetings of the Snow Leopard Conservation Committee conducted with the project support on March 13th in Dushanbe and on May 21st in Khujand. A number of activities of the NAP agreed by the Academy of Sciences was completed and that was reported during Snow Leopard Conservation Committee meetings. 3.4. Under Outcome 3 on regional cooperation, the project made noticeable progress in initiation of transboundary cooperation with Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan on snow leopard monitoring. Despite the fact that COVID19 imposed travel restrictions did not allow the project to conduct face-to-face regional meetings, the draft of the Central Asian Memorandum on conservation of snow leopard ecosystems was finalized in close collaboration with the Global Snow Leopard Programme through online and email consultations, and was submitted for consideration of respective Governments in Central Asia. 3.5. Knowledge resources on snow leopard and project achievements have been demonstrated at more than 14 national (workshops) in Rasht, Aini, Shahristan, Dashtijum, Shakhrinav, Lakhsh, Sangvor, Shurabad districts and the cities of Bokhtar, Kulyab, Khujand and Khorog, and 2 conferences (1 on tourism and 1 conference dedicated to International Snow Leopard Day). The achievements of the project were demonstrated in 2 international webinars (workshops) on gender and environment issues. 3.6. As of today, national coverage of snow leopard and prey monitoring activities makes 22% of snow leopard range and 18% of its prey range. During 2019-2020, the project and its partners (within the agreements concluded to cover wider area by monitoring and other activities) supported installation of 70 camera traps in Sangvor and Lakhsh sections of Tajik NP, Sarikhosor Nature Park, Zorkul Reserve, Karatag Reserve in Shahrinav, and within habitat areas in Khorog and Murghab. The territories of Muk and Kandok (in Lakhsh District), Jartigunbez (Murghab Hunting Agent) and Zorkul became the new areas covered by the project activities on installation of camera traps.

1.1 The total area of protected areas falling under IUCN Category I and II is 2837018 ha. 1.2 The total annual budget allocated for the management of protected areas under IUCN Categories I to IV is $450,000 per year 1.3 METT scores for Sangvor branch of TNP are 66 scores and for Lakhsh branch of TNP is 68 scores 1.4 The number of active rangers in TNP Sangvor branch is 16 and in TNP Lakhsh branch is 18 1.5 More than 85% of Lakhsh and more than 60% of Sangvor TNP sections (including Sangvor reserve) are covered by patrolling. 1.6 At least 2,000 people in project areas, including 1, 100 women, are involved in, and at least 150 people, including 80 women, financially benefit from, working together with the administration of Lakhsh and Sangvor sections of TNP 2.1 The number of days of use of high-altitude pastures in the Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz areas makes 55 days in spring and autumn, and 70 days in summer. 2.2 The productivity of highland pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz has reached 1 ton/ha. 2.3 Percentage (as an average of the total cover per hectare) of palatable and edible species for ungulates and livestock in the high-altitude pastures of the Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz areas increased by 50%. 2.4 At least 7 Pasture User Unions have pasture management plans and are implementing them in the pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz. 2.5 At least 15 households in HissarAlay and Vakhsh-Darvaz directly benefit from technical and grant project support in rehabilitation of snow leopard and prey ecosystems, building basic infrastructure and implementing sustainable management practices for high-altitude pastures and forests. 2.6 At least 5,000 ha of degraded pastures and at least 3,000 ha of degraded forests in Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaz are under active rehabilitation and restoration 2.7 At least 3 Participatory Forest Management (PFM) committees are involved in planning, management and monitoring of highland forests in Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaz areas 2.8 At least 100 persons per year are involved in wildlife monitoring program through training and refresher course on law enforcement 3.1 The methodology of SLIMs monitoring of high-altitude ecosystems, and the tools for its implementation in the Republic of Tajikistan are tested 3.2 Two (2) meetings of National Snow Leopard Conservation Committee held 3.3 The National Action Plan of the Republic of Tajikistan is implemented in model areas 3.4 The resources of knowledge about snow leopards and project achievements are demonstrated at national and international events 3.5 Monitoring activities cover 25% of snow leopard range and 20% of its prey area through wide engagement of responsible stakeholders

1.1. The extent of protected areas under a secure, and effectively managed, monitoring and enforcement regime now totals 434,613 ha (306,613 ha of Sangvor and 69,000 ha of Lakhsh sections of Tajik NP and 59,000 ha of Sangvor Zakaznik). 1.2. Based on the information from the State Institution for Specially Protected Natural Areas, the total annual funding allocation for all categories of protected areas (I-IV) excluding zakazniks in 2021 amounted to TJS 3,500,000 or approx. US$ 309,883 (note: the exchange rate is 11.2946 as of 01/12/2021). Budgetary annual allocations for the State Institution for Specially Protected Natural Areas in 2021 amounted to TJS 894,000 or approx. US$ 79,153 (exchange rate is 11.2946 as of 01/12/2021). Budgetary annual allocations for the Sangvor section of Tajik National Park in 2021 amounted to TJS 157,000 or approx. US$ 13,900 (exchange rate is 11.2946 as of 01/12/2021). Budgetary annual allocations for the Lakhsh section of Tajik National Park in 2021 amounted to TJS 144,426 or approx. US$ 12,787 (exchange rate is 11.2946 as of 01/12/2021). In the aggregate, even though the annual budget allocations increased in local currency since last year, but in US$ terms the annual budget allocation reduced due to local currency depreciation. 1.3. Current METT scores for target PAs: • Lakhsh (Jirgital) section of Tajik NP: 58 (131% of EOP); • Tajik NP (Tavildara, including Sangvor section): 66 (165% of EOP). 1.4. The number of active patrol rangers constitute 32 individuals, of which 16 rangers in Lakhsh section of Tajik NP and 16 rangers in Sangvor section of Tajik NP. The project continues to cover 50% of the rangers’ salary fund, for 8 rangers in Sangvor section of Tajik NP and 10 rangers in Lakhsh section of Tajik NP. 1.5. The coverage of PA areas under a secure and effective monitoring and enforcement regime is 50% for Lakhsh (Jirgital), and 60% for Sangvor (Tavildara) sections of Tajik NP. The patrolling coverage by each ranger reaches 20,000 hectares of the protected area. Totally, ranger patrols cover 200,000 ha of Sangvor section and 50,000 ha of Lakhsh section of Tajik NP. 1.6. 2,000 people (of them 500 women) participated in 48 meetings and consultations, information events, workshops and trainings and relevant project activities on smart patrolling, public monitoring and protection of snow leopard ecosystems. More than 600 people (80 of them women), including 18 rangers, 2 community liaison experts, financially benefited from engagement in protection and patrolling by enjoying preferences in collection of forest resources, firewood, medicinal herbs, bee-keeping activities and use of pastures in favorable conditions. 2.1. The number of days of use of high-altitude pastures in Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz areas has decreased by 10-15 days and makes 50-55 days in spring and autumn, and 60-70 days in summer. In some mountain regions, livestock movement to spring high-altitude pastures started in late March - early April 2021 (as depended on favorable climatic conditions in the areas). Due to abundant vegetation, in the northern part of the country livestock movement begins in mid-May. 2.2. Late livestock movement in spring-autumn period (end of April - beginning of May), conditioned by weather conditions, contributed to the increase of pasture productivity by 3-4 times. Monitoring of productivity of high-altitude pastures by determining the capacity of pasture ecosystems in the project areas of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz indicated variation of pasture productivity from 2.5 to 3 t / ha of dry mass and 4.5 t / ha of green mass (and up to 5.5 t / ha of green mass in several key areas). 2.3. According to project experts’ estimations, 45-60% of palatable and edible species grow in the high mountain pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz districts. The share of palatable and edible species was estimated during field expeditions and by using 1х1 m2 mowing method in key areas of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz. 2.4. To date 7 pasture management plans and regulations/charter have been developed for Pasture Users Unions with project facilitation. The charters are being negotiated with local administrations/hukumats and jamoats of Khovaling, Muminabad, Sangvor and Lakhsh districts in order to establish Pasture Users Union for effective management of high-altitude pastures in Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz districts. 2.5. In the period of end of 2020 – beginning of 2021, the project supported 12 small grants projects with a total of benefiting directly to 2,608 people (1,685 men and 923 women or 435 households), as well indirectly to 7,636 people (4,370 men and 3,266 women or 1,272 households), segregated by thematic activities as below: • 30 ha of pasture and 50 ha of forest ecosystems have been restored and rehabilitated in Tojikobod district, jamoat Kalai Labiob, settlement Kapali, Sangvor district, jamoat Sangvor, Sangvor settlement, Muminobod district, jamoat Balhobi, Selchiyon settlement, Shamsiddin Shokhin district, jamoat Shurobod, Shurobad settlement, jamoat Langar, Langar settlement, jamoat Dashtijum, Diiho settlement, Darvaz district, jamoat Vanj, Vanj settlement. Beneficiaries of this initiative are 5,086 people of them 722 men and 398 women are direct beneficiaries and 2,055 men and 1,911 women are indirect beneficiaries. Along with that, 2 corrals for 800-1,500 heads of small and heavy cattle capacity and a house for shepherds were built in Baljuvon district, jamoat Baljuvon, settlement Horma, Shamsiddin Shokhin district, jamoat Shurobod, settlement Shurobod. Beneficiaries of this initiative are 1,978 people, of them 298 men and 210 women are direct beneficiaries and 865 men and 605 women are indirect beneficiaries. • Ecological tourism and community patrolling project in jamoat Sari Hosor of Baljuvon district benefited totally 580 people, of them 280 men and 100 women direct beneficiaries, and 100 men and 100 women indirect beneficiaries. • 2 projects on beekeeping development were implemented in Shamsiddin Shokhin, jamoat Chagam, settlement Chagami Miyona, Sangvor, jamoat Sangvor, settlement Sangvor, where 450 bee-families were provided. Beneficiaries of this initiative are 2,600 people, of them 385 men and 215 women are direct beneficiaries, and 1,350 men and 650 women are indirect beneficiaries. 2.6. During the reporting period of 2020-2021 alone, 2,000 hectares of forests were moved under restoration/rehabilitation regime in Sangvor, Lakhsh, Rasht and Shamsiddin Shohin districts. Along with that, 50 ha of high-altitude forests were restored by dehkan farms in Shamsiddin Shohin, Tojikobod, Darvaz, Muminobod and Sangvor districts under the project small grants support to public organizations. 2.7. The project actively cooperates with PFM committees and representatives of forest agencies in implementation of project activities. During the reporting period, project experts held 4 meetings with PFM committees in Sangvor, Shahristan and Shamsiddin Shohin districts. A series of methodological guidelines on restoration of forests were disseminated among the PFM committees and environmental agencies. 2.8. During the reporting period, 495 people (including 58 women) were involved in training and professional development programs on wildlife monitoring and law enforcement. Project partners organized 10 workshops on biodiversity conservation and wildlife monitoring, improvement of law enforcement, attended by representatives of the Committee for Environmental Protection, Forestry Agency, local administration, farmers, communities, etc. - totally 178 attendees, including 18 women. 8 workshops and trainings on public monitoring, data transfer and improving law-enforcement were offered to customs services, border guards and environmental protection authorities in trans-border landscapes of Rasht, Lakhsh, Dashtijum and Iskanderkul (totally attended by 240 participants, including 20 women). A scientific conference in Dushanbe, dedicated to the International Snow Leopard Day, allowed discussions on conservation of snow leopard and its ecosystems, monitoring and transboundary cooperation between scientists, specialists and representatives of international organizations (totally attended by 47 participants, including 20 women). 3.1. The methodology of SLIMs monitoring and tools for its implementation in the Republic of Tajikistan were tested and through trainings and workshops presented to nature protection institutions. 1 training on monitoring (in Sarikhosor Jamoat) and 6 workshops on national monitoring and reporting system and SLIM monitoring were offered in Kulob, Bokhtar, Shamsiddin Shohin, Khorog and Dushanbe. More than 120 specialists from environmental agencies and stakeholders, including the Committee for Environmental Protection, State Institution for Specially Protected Natural Areas, National Academy of Sciences and its Institutes, Forestry and other authorities were familiarized and trained in newly developed guiding tools for monitoring, including data collection forms, methodology for assessment and SLIM monitoring, standard procedures for assessing and monitoring of snow leopard ecosystems. 3.2. 2 meetings of National Snow Leopard Conservation Committee were held in 2021 addressing, without limitation, monitoring achievements using SMART и SLIM, implementation of selected programs of the Action plan on Snow Leopard Conservation, progress in implementing the LOA with the Academy of Sciences institution, and regional cooperation in conservation of snow leopard and prey ecosystems. 3.3. Currently, in accordance with the project strategy, individual programs of the NAP are being tested and implemented with the project support by the National Academy of Sciences, its subordinate institutes and other project partners (including Committee for Environmental Protection). The programs under implementation address partners’ capacitation in using innovative technologies, reducing the risk of poaching, and developing programs for research and monitoring of wild ungulates and snow leopards. A dedicated LOA is being implemented with the National Academy of Sciences’ subordinate institution aimed at supporting activities on SLIM monitoring, implementing monitoring routes and interpreting monitoring data. Also, LOAs are concluded with public organizations “Noosfera” and “Women of Pamir Mountains”, and being implemented, aimed at capacitation trainings in project areas devoted to GSLEP monitoring principles, combating poaching and preventing illegal trade with wildlife products. Once the NAP programs are tested, its best practices and results will be reviewed by the National Snow Leopard Conservation Committee at dedicated national workshop. 3.4. Knowledge resources on snow leopard and project achievements were demonstrated at more than 19 national workshops in the districts of Aini, Sh. Shohin and cities of Bokhtar, Kulyab, and Dushanbe in which more than 450 participants took part. In 2021, nation-wide workshops, conferences and festivals on the snow leopard involved more than 7,000 local community members. The brightest events became the Snow Leopard Festival in Shamsidin Shokhin district, Bars in the City initiative and Snow Leopard Cup contest in Dushanbe, which marked the International Snow Leopard Day, thus raising awareness about the importance of biodiversity conservation and sustainable use in the country. News on the project activities and snow leopard conservation are periodically published; and one of the issues of the ecological newspaper “Inson va Tabiat” was specifically devoted to project interventions on conservation of snow leopard ecosystems. The achievements of the project were demonstrated in 2 international online webinars. These events included International Forum on Sustainable Development Goals and Steering Committee of GSLEP-2021. 3.5. As of today, the national coverage of snow leopard and prey monitoring activities makes 25% of snow leopard range and 20% of its prey range, thus reaching the EoP target for this indicator.

1.1. Regulatory documents, a register of land users, a land allotment act and a draft decree in the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan have been developed to change the status of Sangwor Wildlife Preserve and its inclusion into Sangwor TNP with an area of 365613 hectares, which will serve as a good reason to raise the status and legal regime of Sangwor National Park to a higher level according to IUCN requirements.
The package of regulatory documents was submitted to the project partner of the GU SPNA for submission to the Government of Tajikistan.
1.2. The total annual provision for all protected areas (I to IV) in 2019 is estimated at TJS 3,320,000 (US$ 342,585,90; note: exchange rate 9.6910 at 01.02.2009).
The budget for Sangwor TNP in 2019 was TJS 147,000 or USD 15,168.71. The budget of TNP Lyakhsh was TJS 122,000 or USD 12,589.
1.3. Under the agreement with the GU PA partner, the project supported an additional ranger with a monthly fee of USD 10,800. Under the agreement with the GU SPNA partner, the project supported an additional ranger with a monthly fee of US$ 10,800, as well as communication and communication facilities, furniture, etc.
1.4. About 50% of the total area of Sangwor TNP (including Sangwor Wildlife Refuge) and 60% of Lyakhsh TNP are under safe and effective monitoring and enforcement regime due to increased number of rangers, improved technical capacity and support for skills development.
The capacity of the Sangwor (Tavildara) and Liakhsh (Jirgatol) NP sites has been strengthened: - Sangwor and Liakhsh TNPs and community liaison officers have been provided with the necessary equipment and communication facilities to monitor and protect snow leopard ecosystems; - Construction of 2 checkpoints and barriers in Sangwor TNP was completed to strengthen the monitoring and protection regime of the protected area; - 4 workshops and 2 trainings were conducted for 80 employees and government officials of TNP Sangvor and TNP Lyakhsh on methods of monitoring and recording wild animals, principles of using smart patrol system; use of photo traps to determine presence and traces of wild animals such as snow leopards and use of these data in reporting materials; - 10 seminars were held jointly with the project partner GU SPNA with the participation of 200 protected area staff on the use of smart patrol system SMART and field monitoring using GPS and GIS system and installation of camera traps. - 40 photo traps were installed in the territory of TNP Sangvor, TNP Lyakhsh, Sarikhosor Nature Park and TNP Pamir.
1.5. Agreement has been reached with the PA administration and the local communities around TNP Sangwor and TNP Lyakhsh to participate in the protection and prevention of illegal hunting and poaching.
Local communities around the protected areas benefit from the sustainable use of biodiversity resources by increasing yields, regulating nature use and harvesting forest products.
More than 600 people living in Sangwora and 300 people in Lyaksha National Park participate in the protection and management of protected areas and benefit from the collection of forest products, medicinal herbs and the use of pastures on beneficial terms.
Community Liaison Experts in Sangwor TNP and Liakhsh TNP carry out activities with local communities, particularly women and youth, on the importance of preserving snow leopard ecosystems and benefiting from participation in protected areas. 10 workshops and open lessons were held with 70 students and youth on the conservation of Snow leopard ecosystems and hunting sites.
2.1. GU Pasture Reclamation Trust developed norms and standards for restoration of degraded high mountain pastures and recommendations and proposals on reducing the number of days of use of high mountain pastures in Gissaro Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz.
4 seminars were held with 80 participants from the Ministry of Agriculture and APT on the introduction and use of norms and standards for the restoration of degraded pastures and recommendations to reduce the number of days of use of high mountain pastures.
GU Pasture Reclamation Trust received 8000 bales of hay (alfalfa, wheat) to reduce the burden on pastures and late distillation of livestock on high mountain pastures.
2.2. Project experts developed recommendations to improve degraded pastures and reduce the number of days of pasture use in pastures. The area, productivity and condition of rangelands were assessed and determined in Gissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaza project areas.
During the assessment of pasture lands in Sogd, Khatlon, DRD and GBAO, pasture area (1.5 million ha) as well as productivity and edible green mass (33.8 centners/ha) and volume of edible dry mass (8 centners/ha) were determined.
2.3. As a result of reconnaissance studies, high altitude pastures in Gissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaza areas were assessed, pasture pressure and pasture potential were identified and appropriate recommendations were made for rehabilitation and restoration of degraded pastures.
Project experts on TV and radio presented interviews and presentations on methods to reduce the number of days of use of high mountain pastures and regulation of animal husbandry in snow leopard areas.
Regarding the productivity of pastures, the correct use of forage crops for pasture restoration (wild alfalfa, clover, sainfoin, team hedgehog, etc.) was recommended. 8 types of fodder crops seeds (4000 kg), 6 thousand seedlings of forest crops and 18 units of equipment and tools were given to APP and forestry departments of Ayni, Shahristan, Rasht, Sangvor, Lyakhsh, Tajikabad, Muminabad, Khovaling, Shokhin and Baljuvan project districts for restoration and rehabilitation of 100 degraded pastures and 10 hectares of degraded forests.
The conducted pasture assessments show that the tasty and edible qualities of forage crops in the high mountainous pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaza make 50-60% (average of the total grass cover per hectare).
2.4. Representatives of the Users Range Association (URA) actively participate in the project activities on rehabilitation of degraded pastures.
In 3 consultation meetings, 30 APP representatives participated and improved their skills and knowledge on how to improve degraded pastures and reduce the number of days of high mountain pasture use.
3 APTs have signed pasture management plans in Shahristan and are implementing them.
2.5. The following projects are being implemented under TFM for the period 2019: - Introduction of energy-efficient technologies in Jamoat Ivan Tojik Gorno of Matchinsky district (508 men and 246 women directly benefit, and 24894 men and 12093 women indirectly from nearby settlements); - Construction of a enclosure (kashara) for 600 heads of livestock in Dashtijum jamoat of Sh. Shohins district to reduce conflicts with wild animals (5 men and 3 women benefit directly, and 18 men and 12 women indirectly); - Restoration of 6 hectares of forests and 4 hectares of pastures in snow leopard area in the Dashtijum Jamoat of Shamsiddin Shokhin district (direct benefit of 5 households or 20 men and 5 women and indirect benefit of 220 people, of which 150 men and 70 women). In total 541 people directly benefit from participation in grant initiatives of the project and 25144 people indirectly benefit from it.
2.6. 8 species of fodder crop seeds (4000 kg), 6000 seedlings of forest plants were purchased and handed over to Pasture User Associations in Ayni, Shahristan, Rasht, Sangvor, Lyakhsh, Tajikabad, Baljuvan, Muminabad, Khovaling and Shokhin project districts for restoration and rehabilitation of degraded pastures and forests. They also received 18 items of equipment and tools (shovels, mowers, mini-tractors, etc.) for rehabilitation of pastures and forests.
Thus, it contributes to the restoration of 1000 hectares of pastures and about 100 hectares of forests by planting fodder crops and forest species and will continue to work in accordance with the weather conditions from March to June 2020 and concrete results on the ground.
2.7. Three consultative meetings were held with the participation of 50 representatives of forest enterprises and Forest Management Committees (FMCs) in Ayni, Shahristan and Shamsiddin Shahin, where needs and areas of cooperation with the project on rehabilitation of degraded forests were identified. The technical capacity of local forestry departments in 10 project districts was strengthened through the transfer of seeds and seedlings for fodder and forest crops and agricultural tools for planting the forest.
More than 50 representatives of the forest sector participated in the project workshops and trainings and improved their knowledge on rehabilitation of high mountain pastures and fieldwork in high mountain conditions.
2.8. The project partners developed a short-term training programme and modules on monitoring, law enforcement and management of wildlife in forest and rangeland areas. The project offered 20 workshops on wildlife monitoring and management to more than 200 participants, including representatives of the Environmental Protection Committee, State Nature Protection Agency, Forestry Agency, local administration, communities, farmers, etc.
A wildlife monitoring center was established in Sarikhosor Jamoat, Baljuvan district, which will serve as a basis for collection of data on wildlife monitoring and demonstration site for introduction of alternative energy technologies.
3.1. Key elements of Snow Leopard Information Management System (SLIMS) are identified as result of consultations held by the project during the reporting period. Specifically, the consultations of the PIU with the Next GIS developers in Moscow contributed to gaining the theoretical basis and innovative monitoring technologies for further projecting the concept and practicing SLIM monitoring in Tajikistan.
The SLIMS is currently practically implemented by the project within the integral components as follows: 1) developing monitoring routs; 2) monitoring with camera traps (the project provided relevant capacity building planform through procurement of camera traps and offering relevant trainings to ensure that the state control agencies and community organizations have access to camera traps and relevant how-to knowledge); conducting an inventory (which is conducted and the results published on inventory of angulates; regarding snow leopards the calculation method is being used, the key principles of which, recommended for the countries for the snow leopard range were articulated during the regional meeting conducted by the project in Sughd region in April).
3.2. As of the reporting period, the national coverage of snow leopard and prey monitoring activities made 19% of snow leopard range and 14% of its prey range. Relevant activities to support these achievements included, without limitation, below: - Field monitoring of ecosystems (assessment of their productivity) was conducted with the participation of scientists from Russia (monitoring in Dashtijum, Sarihasor districts), Korea and Uzbekistan (monitoring in Kuraminsky ridge and Asht district); - Field monitoring was carried out by project partners, including in the protected areas and beyond. - Public monitoring conducted in the cross-border area with Uzbekistan, in the Hissar zakaznik, the Hiloli jamoat; - Routes and procedures for an aerial survey were designed and developed; - MoU drafted and signed with the Aga Khan Agency for Habitat, that resulted in a number of joint initiatives including a series of joint workshops attended by a representative of the global Snow Leopard Trust on effective cooperation in a number of project initiatives in Tajikistan, implementation of the NAP and the actions to fulfill the GSLEP obligations of Tajikistan. - Consultations were held with the Committee of Tourism Development on the development of ecotourism for sustainable functioning of local communities in mountainous areas. As a continuation, a national conference devoted to International Wildlife Day was held in partnership with the Committee of Tourism Development attended by travel agencies and the partners interested in developing ecotourism in support of the culture and traditional knowledge of the snow leopard, that, without limitation, was aimed at discussing the involvement of communities in overseeing and monitoring activities. - The project established collaboration with the UNDP SGP-GEF on a strategy of public support for snow leopard conservation, that is aimed at collaboration and partnership with grantees to enhance the capacities and effectiveness of actions taken for snow leopard conservation; - The project expert prepared a review and study on the capacities for developing of a new tourist package “Following the footprints of snow leopard”; - Demonstration events (photo exhibition, posters, publications, equipment) were conducted devoted to the World Environment Day, held within the project relevant activities on supporting the environment protection agenda of the project partner – the Committee for Environmental protection; - A national conference was held devoted to the Snow Leopard International Day that allowed to disseminate and share project experience (photo essays, exhibitions, presentations, videos), initiate discussions, including on snow leopard monitoring issues, and outline new partnership links.
3.3. Currently the drafted National Action Plan for the Conservation of Snow Leopard Ecosystems in Tajikistan is being implemented with the project support in a part of commonality of the project interventions and relevant NAP actions. Priority programs for implementation are reviewed and approved at the meetings of the National Committee, and the results of works will serve as the basis for best practices in the formation of the final version of the NAP. The below activities were held, without limitation, to support NAP implementation: - Training on using drones for landscaping survey and decoding was offered to scientists and practitioners; - A national workshop on NAP was held to harmonize it with the new GSLEP principles and priorities; - GIS training was conducted during 6 days for scientists and researchers to support the NAP implementation; - Regional scientific conference on biodiversity, embracing the CIS countries, was held in partnership with the project partner the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Tajikistan in Khujand, were the session was included The state of snow leopard ecosystems that allowed relevant discussions and experience exchange; - The project performed comprehensive legal and technical review of the draft Memorandum and Action Plan on joint actions for conservation of snow leopards’ landscapes in Western Tien Shan and Pamir Alay (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan). The text of the Memorandum has been submitted to the concerned ministries and agencies for the review and the following submission to the Government for approval.
3.4. - To strengthen cross-border cooperation in the region, the project organized a regional meeting in the Sughd region with the participation of Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Russia. Representatives of GSLEP, international organizations accredited in the Republic of Tajikistan, such as Aga Khan Agency for Habitat, Fauna and Flora International, the European Union, UNDP and others also took part in the meeting. As a result of this meeting, the Sughd Resolution was adopted reflecting the decisions taken on the implementation of measures on conservation of the snow leopard ecosystems at the regional level. More than 50 people (of them 12 women), including government representatives and specialists of environmental organizations of Tajikistan, Russia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan (17 persons), national and international scientists (6 persons), representatives of national and international NGOs including GSLEP, WWF, European Union, AKAH (7 persons), as well as representatives of the United Nations Development Programme in Tajikistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan (10 persons) took part in the meeting. - 4 scientists from Russian Federation (3 males and 1 female) took part in the project activities on assessments of transboundary snow leopard habitat areas, collection of samples, assessment of natural resistance behavior and of anthropogenic load. - 2 PIU representatives (1 male and 1 female) conducted consultations on the methods of snow leopard materials collection and analysis held during relevant project mission to Russian Federation and meetings with the developers of the smart patrol system and the A.N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution. - 2 project staff and 4 partner representatives participated in the Fourth Steering Committee New Delhi, India, which allowed coordination of the project activities in accordance with the ongoing global developments. As a result, a national meeting was held to form relevant understanding by a wide audience (experts, specialists, public organizations) of new priorities of the Bishkek Declaration; - 5 project, government and Academy of Sciences’ representatives took part in the Workshop for Snow Leopard Range Countries in Central Asia Transboundary cooperation on the conservation of the snow leopard and the prevention of illegal trade in biological objects” in Bishkek, Kyrgyz Republic.
3.5. Three National Snow Leopard Conservation Committee meetings were held in 2019.

1.1. The total area of protected areas falling under IUCN Category I and II is 2837018 ha. 1.2. The total annual budget allocated for the management of protected areas under IUCN Categories I to IV is S450.000 per year. 1.3. METT scores for Sangvor branch of TNP are 66 and for Lakhsh branch of TNP is 68. 1.4. The number of active rangers in TNP Sangvor branch is 16 and in TNP Lakhsh branch is 18. 1.5. More than 85% of Lakhsh and more than 60% of Sangvor TNP sections (including Sangvor reserve) are under safe and effective monitoring and enforcement regime. 1.6. At least 2,000 people, including 1,100 women, are involved in the project areas and at least 150 people, including 80 women, benefit financially from working together with the administration of Lakhsh and Sangvor sections of TNP. 2.1. An overview of the status of days of grazing (spring/autumn and summer) in the high mountain pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz is prepared and submitted to the project Steering Committee; 2.2. The productivity of highland pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz makes 1 ton/ha; 2.3. The total grass/forb/herb cover per hectare of palatable and edible species for ungulates and livestock in the high-altitude pastures of the Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz areas increased in 50% in average. 2.4. At least 10 Pasture User Unions (as per the project goal) have approved pasture management plans and are implementing them in the pastures of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh-Darvaz; 2.5. At least 3 Participatory Forest Management (PFM) committees (as per the project goal) are involved in planning, management and monitoring of highland forests of Hissar-Alay and Vakhsh Darvaz; 2.6. At least 100 persons per year are involved in wildlife monitoring program through training and refresher course on law enforcement. 3.1. The methodology of SLIMs monitoring of high-altitude ecosystems, and the tools for its implementation in the Republic of Tajikistan are developed and tested. 3.2. At least 2 meetings of the National Snow Leopard Conservation Committee held. 3.3. Action Plan of the Republic of Tajikistan is submitted to the Government of Tajikistan for approval. 3.4. Agreement of Central Asian countries on snow leopard ecosystem conservation signed and is implemented per priority areas with partners/countries of the region. 3.5. Knowledge resources on snow leopard and project achievements are demonstrated at least at 3 international and national events. 3.6. Monitoring activities cover 25% of snow leopard range and 20% of its prey area.
